comment._content: Story of the wireless icongraph ( a sort of early fax machine) from New York times of 1912. "YOUNG INVENTOR'S SUCCESS.; Patents Granted to Italian for His "Wireless Iconograph." Special Correspondence THE NEW YORK TIMES. July 14, 1912, Sunday LONDON, July 2. -- The Milan correspondent of The Daily Chronicle sends some interesting details of the life of Francesco de Bernocchi, the young Italian scientist who has invented the "wireless iconograph," which will transmit messages, sketches, autographs, shorthand, and other signs." Unfortunately it appears you have to pay to read the rest of the story... at query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9500E5DD123CE633A... NYTimes also has a other story a few days later direct from Italy WIRELESS DEVICE SENDS HANDWRITING; The Iconograph Also Reproduces Shorthand and Cryptograms Between Milan and Turin. See query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D03E0D81F31E233A... Meanwhile Amazon is flogging originals at 137$... www.amazon.com/Newswire-Photo-Bermocchi-wireless-iconogra... See also another photograph of the machine on the Commons www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2765468646/ ....
